Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Next Generation Neutrino Water Cherenkov Detectors Using Large-Area Fast Photosensors
Award.AbstractNarration:
Neutrinos possibly hold the key to some of the most fundamental questions still to be answered: why is universe dominated only by matter and what role did neutrinos play in the evolution of the universe. To seek an answer to these questions, we are about to embark in perhaps the largest enterprise that the neutrino community has known: the Long Baseline Neutrino Experiment (LBNE). It implies sending a powerful beam of neutrinos 800-miles through the earth from Fermilab (Illinois) to two detectors underground in the Homestake mine (South Dakota). The goal of this proposal is to replace the current standard of photodetection technology, photomultiplier tubes (PMTs), with a more modern option. Advances in material science and nano-technology provide the opportunity to extend the concept of microchannel plates to large-area, economical photodetectors with inherently good space and time resolution.

This award provides funding for the simulation, characterization and calibration design for these devices with the goal of demonstrating their superiority with respect to standard PMTs in the next generation of Water Cherenkov detectors for neutrino physics.

Broader impacts:
The award will also fund an outreach program that will focus on augmenting recruiting and retention of female undergraduates in STEM majors at Iowa State University, with an emphasis on the Physics & Astronomy Department. The PI will establish a Women in Physics group to get undergraduate and graduate students together for interaction and mentorship. In addition, the PI in collaboration with undergraduate students will develop hands-on activities to be presented in the K-12 outreach programs sponsored by the Program for Women in Science and Engineering at Iowa State.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Neutrinos possibly hold the key to some of the most fundamental questions still to be answered: why is universe dominated only by matter and what role did neutrinos play in the evolution of the universe. To seek an answer to these questions, we must seek to observe these particles in new and innovative ways. One possible neutrino detector type, so-called Water Cherenkov, uses water for the neutrinos interact and the resulting charged particles generate light that travel to photo-detection devices installed in the surface of a volume. 

Advances in material science and nano-technology provide the opportunity to extend the concept of an existing technology (microchannel plates) to large-area, economical photodetectors with inherently good space and time resolution. A consortium of national laboratories, universities and industry has developed a new kind of large-area fast photosensors based on this concept. These detectors are named LAPPDs for Large-Area Picosecond Photo-Detectors. 

During this award the PI optimized the application of these novel photosensors for large Water Cherenkov detectors. We have shown that these devices have the potential to transform the physics capabilities of future neutrino experiments by enhancing the vertex resolution and thus background rejection. The developed reconstruction takes full advantage of the features of new fast photodetectors such as LAPPDs and use it on various detector configurations. We identified time residuals as a key reconstruction feature that would allow to use the improved time resolution of the new photodetectors and we reached the conclusion that we can use the improvements in vertex resolution as a proxy for better background rejection. In practice good vertex resolution would allow neutral pion/electron separation by distinguishing between two and one vertex. 

When using photosensors with better timing and spacial resolution, we must account for chromatic dispersion, which becomes an important effect in very large detectors.We have shown that by exploiting the features of new photosensors, we can achieve 4- 6 cm resolutions in vertex reconstruction in the transverse direction for mono energetic muons and electrons in 200 kton and 500 kton detectors. 

The PI also designed a highly leveraged Water Cherenkov experiment which allows for the first application of LAPPDs for neutrino detection. The Atmospheric Neutrino Neutron Interaction Experiment (ANNIE), is devised to measure the neutron yield of atmospheric neutrino interactions in gadolinium-doped water. This measurement is key in order to demonstrate the potential of neutron tagging in eliminating the atmospheric neutrino background to proton decay. The ANNIE experiment uses the existing Booster Neutrino Beam with a small water tank located in the SciBooNE hall at Fermilab. It provides an excellent environment in which to test and demonstrate the performance of LAPPDs. 

The experiment has been approved for an initial phase and it is currently taking data at Fermilab. Neutrinos have been observed. The interest in the ANNIE experiment demonstrates that the concept of using LAPPDs for water Cherenkov detectors is promising. The experiment is a significant step towards the commercialization of these devices so that it will serve the high energy physics community and beyond. 

In addition to research, the PI also set out tocreate a Women in Physics group in the Department of Physics and Astronomy of Iowa State University. During the Spring 2012, the PI partnered with the Women in Science and Engineering (WiSE) at Iowa State in starting the Women in Physics group. The undergraduates in particular had interest in having a forum to share experiences and find opportunities for professional development, enhance undergraduate recruitment as well as work on outreach to younger women. Since then the group has had regular meetings. The group has organized a trip each year to the Conference for Undergraduate Women in Physics. The PI in collaboration with the department has submitted a proposal to host this conference on 2018 at Iowa State and plans to continue attending these conferences with a group of undergraduate students. Several women undergraduate have been mentored within by the PI. Some of these students have participated Student Role Model Program run by WiSE reaching about 2900 students through that program alone. The Women in Physics group has had a role in inspiring these students to reach out to younger female students acting as role models and at the same time strengthening their own physicist/science identity.
